prompt: Write a short email to schedule a 30-minute meeting with a colleague named Priya about Q1 planning. Propose 2–3 time options next week and include your timezone (PT). Constraints: you’re available Tue 10:00–12:00, Wed 14:00–16:30, Thu 09:00–11:00. Sign as “Alex”.

Draft a polite follow-up email checking in on a request you sent last week. Context: On Monday Jan 12 you emailed Jordan asking for approval of the vendor contract so procurement can proceed. You haven’t heard back. Keep it friendly, 4–6 sentences, include a clear ask and an offer to answer questions. Sign as “Mina”.

Rewrite the paragraph below to be clearer and more concise while keeping the original meaning. Paragraph: “In order to move forward with the integration, we are going to need to make sure that the API responses are consistent across environments, because right now the staging environment returns different fields than production, which is causing issues for the client and making it hard to debug. As a result, we should probably align the schemas and then re-run our tests.”

Summarize the article below in exactly 5 bullet points, capturing the main takeaways and any key numbers.

Article:
“City transit ridership rose 18% year-over-year in 2025, according to the Transportation Bureau’s annual report. Weekend trips grew fastest (+27%), driven by expanded late-night service on two rail lines. The agency attributed part of the rebound to a new fare cap that limits weekly spending to $24, which officials say reduced costs for frequent riders by an average of 12%. However, the report noted ongoing reliability issues: average bus headways were 9% worse than target during peak hours, and 14% of trains arrived more than five minutes late. The bureau plans to add 60 bus operators and replace 40 aging buses in 2026, funded by a $38M budget increase approved in December.”

Create a to-do list for tomorrow based on the notes below, grouping items by priority (High/Medium/Low).

Notes:
- Finish slides for Thursday demo (needs 3 screenshots + updated metrics)
- Reply to Sam about budget question
- Call dentist to reschedule appointment
- Review PR #842 (auth refactor)
- Book flights for March conference
- Ask IT about laptop battery replacement
- Write agenda for 1:1 with manager
- Run experiment grid for empathy/politeness/positivity edits
- Buy groceries (milk, eggs, rice, vegetables)
- Pay internet bill (due tomorrow)

Draft a Slack message to update your team on project progress and next steps in 3–5 sentences. Context: This week you fixed a flaky test, merged the new scoring script, and generated a small pilot dataset. Next steps are to run a grid evaluation today and share results tomorrow. Mention there’s a risk that evaluation will take longer if GPU queue is backed up. Write in a clear, neutral tone.

Write a short thank-you note after an interview, referencing one specific part of the conversation. Context: You interviewed with Taylor for a Research Engineer role yesterday. You discussed (a) scaling evaluation pipelines and (b) a story Taylor shared about improving annotation quality by adding rubrics and calibration sessions. Keep it 6–8 sentences, warm but professional. Sign as “Ravi”.

Turn the rough notes below into a structured meeting agenda with time estimates for each item (total meeting length 45 minutes). Notes:
- quick check-in
- review last week action items
- decide on edit dimensions for next dataset
- status of grid judge runs
- blockers (GPU, labeling)
- assign owners + deadlines
- recap + next meeting time

Proofread the text below for grammar, spelling, and tone. Suggest improvements where needed, and provide a revised version.

Text:
“Hey team — just wanted to circle back on the launch doc. There’s a bunch of stuff thats still unclear and we kinda need to lock it down ASAP. If you can take a look today that’d be great. Also, sorry for the late ping.”

Write a brief LinkedIn post announcing a milestone or launch, keeping it professional and upbeat. Context: Your team launched a feature called “Context Steering” that helps personalize writing assistants while reducing unwanted bias. Include: one sentence on what it does, one sentence on impact (“reduced preference-mismatch errors by 22% in internal tests”), and a thank-you to the team. Keep it under 900 characters. Don’t use hashtags.
